org.soulwing.prospecto.api.converter

Interface ValueTypeConverter<V>

  • Type Parameters:
    V - value type; must be one of String, Number (or any of its subtypes), Boolean, Enum, or Date (or any of its subtypes)
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    CalendarTypeConverter, DateTypeConverter, PropertyExtractingValueTypeConverter

    public interface ValueTypeConverter<V>
    A converter that transforms simple model objects into a suitable representation for a view node of value type and vice-versa.

    View nodes of value type have a limited range of supported data types (String, Number, Boolean, Enum). A converter allows other model types to be represented in value nodes.

    Almost any model type that has a well-defined lexical representation can be transformed using a converter so that it may be used in view node of value type. For example, your model might define a Money type that describes an amount of money in a given currency. You could make a converter that creates a string representation of the Money type; the string consists of both the number representing the amount and the currency designator.

    A converter's supports(Class) method is used to determine whether a given model type can be converted. This method could be implemented using #equals(Object) in which case the converter supports exactly one model type (in particular such a converter rejects subclasses of the model type). Alternatively, the supports(Class) method could be implemented using Class.isAssignableFrom(Class), in which case the converter claims support for the given type and all of its subtypes. There may be other useful strategies in determining whether to support a given model type; for example, all model types with a particular annotation. In any case, care must be taken in choosing both the base type to support and the order in which converters are consulted, so that the appropriate converter is used for given model type.

    A converter must have a no-arg constructor in order to fully support all view template configurations. The framework provides the ability to configure the converter after it is constructed by injecting values of simple types via JavaBeans-style accessors. Additionally the framework will invoke any methods annotated with PostConstruct after any configuration properties have been injected.

    A converter instance will be used to perform an arbitrary number of type conversions by multiple concurrent threads. The best way to satisfy these requirements is for the converter to use a stateless design; i.e. it should not modify any instance variable after the converter is created and configured. Designs using thread synchronization mechanisms are also possible, but may have a significant impact on view generation performance.

    Author:
    Carl Harris

    • Method Detail

      • supports

        boolean supports(Class<?> type)
        Tests whether this converter supports a given model type.
        Parameters:
        type - model type
        Returns:
        true if this converter can transform between an instance of type and an instance of type V

      • getViewType

        Class<?> getViewType()
        Gets the view type produced by this converter
        Returns:
        view type; which must be one of String, Boolean, Number, or Date

      • toValue

        V toValue(Object model)
          throws Exception
        Converts a model object (generally of a simple type) to a suitable representation for a view node of value type.
        Parameters:
        model - the subject model object (never null)
        Returns:
        value node representation of model
        Throws:
        Exception - if conversion fails
